awd_titl_txt: Banach Spaces and Graphs: Geometric Interactions and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
It can arguably be said that the world one lives in is geometric in nature. Numerous practical everyday-life issues, as well as fundamental scientific mysteries, can be expressed in geometric terms. For instance, networks are ubiquitous in our modern society. From the World Wide Web and its powerful search engines to social networks, from telecommunication networks to economic systems, networks represent a wide range of real world systems. They can naturally be seen as geometric objects by considering the number of edges of the shortest path connecting two nodes as a quantity measuring their proximity. The study of physical laws has led as well to the development of a refined mathematical framework where elaborate geometric structures are able to depict and model the interactions of elementary particles and the symmetries underlying quantum physics. The notion of a metric space is a central concept that is pivotal in mathematical models of optimization problems in networks, and in a vast range of application areas, including computer vision, computational biology, machine learning, statistics, and mathematical psychology, to name a few. This extremely useful abstract concept generalizes the classical notion of an Euclidean space, where the distance from point A to point B is computed as the length of an imaginary straight line connecting them. The heart of the matter usually boils down to understanding whether a given metric space, in particular a graph equipped with its shortest path distance, can be faithfully represented in a more structured space, typically a Banach space with some desirable properties. Our ability to do so usually has tremendous applications.

The problems investigated in this project are motivated by their potential applications in theoretical physics and theoretical computer science. Most of the problems considered find their origins either in practical issues (e.g. the design of efficient approximation algorithms), or in fundamental mathematical problems in topology or noncommutative geometry (e.g. the Novikov conjecture(s), the Baum-Connes conjecture(s)). Embedding problems that arise in connection to these problems have been considered independently by several groups of mathematicians (Banach space geometers, geometric group theorists, computer scientists...). An underlined aspect of this proposal is to consider these embeddings problems from a unified and global standpoint. Fundamental and long-standing open problems in quantitative metric geometry (e.g. Enflo's problem, a metric reformulation of uniform smoothability, the coarse embeddability of groups and expander graphs into super-reflexive Banach spaces...) will be tackled from a different angle with new and innovative techniques. In particular, the project will develop a certain asymptotic theory of Banach spaces and explore its connections to the geometry of infinite graphs. The approach here to solve the local problems above, is to study asymptotic counterparts of the local properties involved, in order to gain new insights and to devise new approaches. This approach is motivated by the fact that the asymptotic setting usually provides a finer picture, is on some occasion better understood, and requires completely different techniques. A general outline of the research methodology of this project is to utilize powerful tools from surrounding fields (graph theory, probability theory, Ramsey theory...), and cross-over techniques (e.g. techniques from theoretical computer science to solve geometric group theoretic problems).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main theme of this project was to improve and advance our understanding of the various deep connections between the geometry of purely metric objects (such as metric graphs, abstract metric spaces that do not carry a linear structure...) and the geometry of spaces endowed with a metric together with some additional algebraic structure (normed linear spaces, spaces of operators...).

A significant portion of the work supported by this grant produced results which advanced significantly various aspects of the Ribe program, and the quantitative embeddability theory of metric spaces. Quantitative embedding results were obtained for a class of geometric spaces, called lamplighter metric spaces, whose metrics are induced by some variations of the classical and fundamental Traveling Salesman Problem. Some of these results were obtained upon the realization that these metric spaces which are central objects in geometric group theory can be studied using techniques from the theoretical computer science community, which had been succesfully applied to another fundamental class of metrics (Wasserstein metrics) induced by optimal transport problems.

Two new metric invariants based on the geometry of Hamming graphs were discovered in connection to the asymptotic geometry of Banach spaces. A coarse invariant that takes the form of a concentration inequality for Lipschitz maps on the Hamming graphs was shown to characterize the class of Banach spaces that are reflexive and whose asymptotic structure behaves like the sequence of finite-dimensional spaces with the supremum norm. Within the class of reflexive spaces we gave a bi-Lipschitz characterization of this asymptotic property in terms of preclusion of a collection of certain Hamming-type metrics, in the spirit of Bourgain's celebrated characterization of superreflexivity in terms of preclusion of the sequence of binary trees. 

Similarly to how the Markov convexity (local) metric invariant captures the geometry of the binary trees, several new (asymptotic) metric invariants (umbel convexity, umbel cotype...) were introduced with the goal of capturing the geometry of countably branching trees. During this process we introduced new local metric invariants which offered a different perspective on Markov convexity.

We also introduced a coarse invariant, called upper stability, which in some sense unifies the isometric theory of stable spaces and the isomorphic theory of reflexive spaces.

We proposed analogues in the nonlinear setting of universality results obtained originaly by Bourgain in the linear setting. These results have a descriptive set theoretic flavor.

We also offered a different viewpoint regarding the geometry of doubling metric spaces in connection with the Lang-Plaut problem.

Finally, the rigidity problem for uniform Roe algebras was resolved positively. This problem asked whether two uniformly locally metric spaces that look alike in a certain coarse metric sense, must generate algebras of bounded operators that look alike in a natural algebraic sense. 

The PI ran 4 faculty-led study abroad programs in France between 2016-2019, the last two of them occuring  during the grant period.  One of the main goal of the program was to help students develop a global mindset and awareness that will be crucial in their future professional lives whether it is within or outside of academia or mathematics. Moreover, a priority was to ensure that minority students can take advantage of the study abroad opportunity and make mathematics a central part of their education. Studying abroad is one of the most efficient way to develop a global mindset and mix people with different cultural backgrounds. To further provide the global perspective to the students, the program offers thoughtful cultural activities and the opportunity to perform mathematical collaborative work between US students and French students intervening in the program. The program received more than $50,000 in endowment funds via the ``Joan O. and Jeff L. Bott '65 Endowed Study Abroad Scholarship in Mathematics''. These funds are used in the form of scholarships to enhance the participation of students from underrepresented groups. Students from underrepresented groups (female/first generation/Hispanic origin students) accounted for roughly 75% of every cohort. The post-program evaluations showed the program to be a great asset to retain students in the mathematical fields. About 25% of the students of every cohort changed their career plans to include more mathematics and to actively seek undergraduate research experiences.

Finally, as the first phase of a long term interdisciplinary project, the PI and Texas A&M colleagues Pr. A. Bonito and M. Hielsberg (Institute for Scientific Computation) developed of a new course on ``Mathematical Algorithms and their Implementations''. This hybrid course blends rigorous mathematical treatment of algorithm design and programming in Python (considered as the leading programming language in data science). 

The PI also created a new seminar series ``Metric and Banach space geometry''. This series hosts mathematicians and computer scientists and about 60% of attendees are graduates students and faculty from various departments (e.g. Statistics, Electrical Engineering, Industrial System Engineering, Computer Engineering...).
